article_text:
Despite the Supreme Court decision to uphold the subsidies for private insurance in King v. Burwell, the fundamental problems with the Affordable Care Act remain. Ironically, it is the growing government centralization of health insurance at the expense of private insurance that must be addressed.

The 107 million people on Medicaid or Medicare in 2013 will increase to 135 million by 2018, a growth rate tripling that of private insurance, according to projections by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. At the...

twitter.description: In The Wall Street Journal, Dr. Scott W. Atlas writes that the wreckage from ObamaCare is in urgent need of repair—the King v. Burwell ruling aside, the fact remains that premiums are skyrocketing and choices are shrinking.
twitter.title: Repairing the ObamaCare Wreckage

og.description: In The Wall Street Journal, Dr. Scott W. Atlas writes that the wreckage from ObamaCare is in urgent need of repair—the King v. Burwell ruling aside, the fact remains that premiums are skyrocketing and choices are shrinking.
og.title: Repairing the ObamaCare Wreckage

article_metadata.author: Scott W. Atlas

article_summary:
Ironically, it is the growing government centralization of health insurance at the expense of private insurance that must be addressed.
Despite the Supreme Court decision to uphold the subsidies for private insurance in King v. Burwell, the fundamental problems with the Affordable Care Act remain.
The 107 million people on Medicaid or Medicare in 2013 will increase to 135 million by 2018, a growth rate tripling that of private insurance, according to projections by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.
